Posts.Content: Hi Ruby, I've been undecided whether I should respond to your post or not as my diagnostic experience started very much as your own, for me it turned out I had cancer......DCIS with micro invasions. However what I wanted to say was my calcification clusters had been monitored for 6 years before they changed and became "suspicious", so as others have said just because you have calcification clusters doesn't mean you have cancer. That said I think it's good in an odd way that you are at least considering the fact the news might not be what you want to hear. I say that because I was so blas√© about the whole mammo re-call, biopsy etc. as this was my 3rd re-call, I just hadn't considered the possibility this might not be just another false alarm, so when I got the news it came totally out of the blue and I just wasn't prepared for the news. Others have already said prepare some questions for when you do meet with your doctor, hopefully you won't need them but best to be prepared as your brain will be scrambled if you do get the news you don't want to hear and do take someone with you as you probably won't take everything in, so a friend or relative by your side can really help. Unfortunately waiting for results during this journey is the worst part, I found that as long as I kept busy I was fine, it's the quiet times when fear and worry can sneak up on you, just remember worrying won't change the outcome, so try not to waste your energy and effort on doing so....I know easier said than done but really there's no upside to lingering on negative thoughts. I really hope your results are clear, in the meantime if you want to know anything more about my journey please feel free to PM me. Take care and good luck Amanda

Posts.Content: Ladies, I feel your pain re the weight gain etc. I was dreading that, although it's turned out that like Wendy I've been a weight loser not gainer during treatment. I lost over a stone during chemo which I finished 7 weeks ago. Despite eating for a small army I didn't put on a ounze......"don't worry you'll gain some during radio T" I was told.....had my last RadioT on Monday and over the three weeks I've lost another 4 pounds. "Be grateful" I was told "you'll gain weight once you start Tamoxifen"......I started 3 weeks ago I replied!!!! I really didn't have a Stone + 4/5 lbs to lose, I'm 5.7 and now weight 8 Stone 10lb which is the lowest I've been since my early 20s.....I'm not complaining as I know many ladies would swap with me, although it's not all good........the ever leaner image combined with hair that's still in the early stages of recovery and a wardrobe full of clothes at least 1 size too big for me just adds to the classic "cancer patient" image.....although I NEVER think of myself in that way. I'm just waiting for my body to level out so I can buy myself some clothes that fit........and keeping my fingers crossed that my bum decides to reappear at some point :-) Amanda

Posts.Content: Hi All, I did yoga before my diagnose in Jan 2015, I managed to keep some aspects of it going through treatment and returned to it "properly" about 10 weeks ago. It's been a fantastic help for me both physically and in re adjusting some tamoxifen driven negativity in my moods and attitudes.¬† I've been very fortunate in having a teacher who knew me before and after surgery/treatment and runs small classes, so has the time to go through things with you individually.¬† Given this experience I just wanted to pass on a couple of cautions to ladies/gents considering starting or returning to yoga. 1st ¬†- make sure you find a qualified, reputable teacher, who has had experience in dealing with ladies/gents who have had breast surgery, hopefully any who are recommended by your BCN or Macmillan will meet those criteria. If your new to yoga make sure you start with a beginners class or arrange some 121 sessions before starting a "class".¬† 2nd - make sure your teacher knows your limitations, depending on your surgery you may have been advised not to do certain things e.g. carry weights, although you don't use weights in yoga, you do use your upper body to hold your own weight to one degree or another in certain poses e.g. Downward Dog! A good teacher will be able to adapt poses to fit your limitations.¬† 3rd - go slowly, don't push yourself too much and certainly don't be competitive, your body is recovering from more than just surgery and you hold all your emotional tension and stress in your hips, groins and solar plexus, so it's not just standing on your head that's seriously dangerous if you don't know what your doing. When starting Yoga it's like the swan on the lake, calm on the surface and frantic activity below (thinking about it is always like that :-)) so even the simple poses need to be done properly to avoid injury and reap the real benefits.¬† All that said enjoy it and try to do some practice everyday, even if just 10-15 minutes. After 10 weeks I'm pretty much back to my previous range of movements and my attitude and approach to life is more positive, plus you get to meet some lovely ladies and gents. Namaste¬† CC

Posts.Content: Hi Hevbo......been thinking about Nadjie's advice about exercise, exercise, exercise......which I totally agree with. If you go down the LD Route can I suggest you ask the hospital about their arrangements for post op Physio (if they have any) In my case I had daily Physio for the first 10 days followed by twice weekly physio's for 4 weeks, then weekly Physio for the last 10 weeks (I couldn't manage more than once a week once on Chemo). As you've had chemo your recovery might be shorter. This isn't all for movement following the lumpectomy, more the range of movement and strength in your LD muscle following the surgery, particularly around lengthening the part of the muscle moved into your boob so you can twist, turn and lift your arm in comfort.¬† In an ideal world I'd have seen the Physio before the surgery so we could establish what was "normal" movement before the op. It turned out in my case I already had a shoulder impairment which I knew nothing about before BC, so the Physio has had to work out what restrictions I already had and what's down to the surgery and then work out a recovery plan for both!!¬† I'm almost 4 month post op. and on a day to day basis would say I've had full movement for at least 6 weeks, although the strength of the LD muscle operated on is still less, as a sporty person my expectations of what I can do is probably greater than "normal", I'm hoping my strength will improve once my treatments finished and I can put more effort into building it up again. If your hospital doesn't offer a Physio programme I would recommend you look into what you can arrange for yourself. Amanda

Posts.Content: Hi Karin, actually Mr T hasn't been too bad so far. I know the steroids are a pain but they are really helpful in reducing any initial side effects. The first main difference you might notice is the length of time it takes to administer the drug, mine took 4-4.5 hours, about 2 hours longer than FEC although I was also given an antihistamine and some extra steroids due to a delay in my treatment, you might not get either of these but expect Mr T to take longer. I had some tingling in my toes about an hour after the chemo session finished which lasted about 40 minutes, I was told this was normal although how long it lasts for varies from person to person.¬† I felt fine for the first couple of days but then days +3 to 5 I had some muscle aches, all body tingling and headaches but from day 6 onwards things improved and for the last few days I've felt really good, certainly better than my last couple of FECs. I'm due my 2nd T on Tuesday, so let's hope Tuesday is good to both of us and the week in general kind to all the chemo bunnies. Amanda

Posts.Content: Morning Ladies, wow you were an active bunch yesterday.....good to know we can turn to JCC to share and find emotional and practical support anytime. Well 2nd T + 1 and all pretty much as last time, steriods flush and energy levels although did managed to sleep OK despite the pesky steriods. Karin I'm amazed at the difference in the drug administration time, I have a chemo port in my chest which works pretty much like a PICC line but it's all inside your chest so no awkward bits hanging out ...after the first week when it just felt odd and sore after the op to insert it, I've not had a minutes problem. For those of you having problems with your PICC lines it might be worth asking if your hospital does them, Nadjie has one as well and think she gets on OK with hers to. Again it took about 4 hours 20 to give me the cocktail of drugs with most of that time, 3.5 hours for the Paclitaxel. Bunglesabout...I found out yesterday that I'm actually having Paclitaxel, which is part of the Taxol regime but apparently should have "easier" side effects. In another post George described Paclitaxel as "being hit with a velvet glove rather than a wet leather one" this might explain some of the differences in our experiences but I don't want to get ahead of myself as I've only got 1 of these under my belt so far.....I need to wait until Tomorrow before I'll know how soft or not the side effects are this time round! But your spot on about the meds. I was told right from the get go to get on top of any aches, pains, nausea etc. it's much easier to stop the pain etc. developing than to ease the pains once they've got a hold. Good luck to chemo bunnies having their next sessions today and later in the week, hope it's kind to you. Hugs Amanda

Posts.Content: Hi bm84.......like Nadjie I opted not to use the cold cap, one piece of advice I'd add to Nadjie's post is if you decide not to use the cold cap get your hair cut really short e.g shaved just before or soon after your first chemo.....having your hair really short will help reduce any tingling discomfort leading up to you losing your hair but also the actual loss will be easier, e.g. it doesn't come out in handfuls when your in the shower and short hair doesn't make quite as much mess :-) It's also easier to give your head a massage to encourage the hair to come out once it starts to fall and will makes the process quicker. Sorry if this sounds a little depressing but best to be prepared if you go down this route and on a brighter note....it really isn't as bigger deal as you might think, I lost my hair 7/8 weeks ago but became used to my new image very quickly. Like Nadjie I've got hats, scarfs, cotton beanies etc. but decided against a wig and to be honest I now spend most of my time "commando" as it's cooler and actually people who see me take it they're stride. Anyway the choice is yours..... Hope everything goes well.....good luck and just shout if you have any questions amanda

Posts.Content: Hi Chrissy, I know there are many ladies on this site who can give you better advice than me......but just wanted to say I was where you are two weeks ago.....although not a mastectomy, I had reconstruction at the same time.......all the same I was fearful of the process and how I'd feel afterwards. For me I was amazed at how well I felt within a few hours....totally unexpected. Yes there's some discomfort although mine is all pretty much related to the area used for reconstruction and even then after a couple of days, nothing that over the counter painkillers can't handle. We're all different in how we react and handle these situations but the best bit of advice I received time after time was to BREATH.......deep breaths are best but any kind of conscious breathing helps.......keep your tongue soft/relaxed at the same time.....our body takes it cue from our solar plexus/diaphram.....if you can keep that soft and relax it will Help the rest of you to relax......easier to say than do I know but in my experience it works¬† There is nothing you can do about the operation now so just trust the professionals to do their stuff and save your energy for healing afterwards Wishing you all the very best for Monday¬† CC

Posts.Content: Hi buggy, tough one, I had a lumpectomy 4 weeks ago, stage 2 DCIS with micro invasions, all my lymphs were clear, cancer also ER+. Treatment plans was radiotherapy and Hormone tablets. Tumor biopsy showed it was heterogenous with parts of the tumour having high Ki-67 markers indicating an aggressive element to the tumour. I had a similar conversation with my surgeon about the potential for chemo and was all of a spin.......didn't want it but wanted to do everything I could to beat the C cells. in the end the Oncologists made the decision I should have chemo.......whilst I'm still not sure I want it, having someone else make the decision for me helped. Jackie on this site was a great help to me in coming to terms with having the chemo basically she pointed out that if they told you advance that chemo would give you even a small % improvement/chance of beating cancer/extending your life....wouldn't you take it? Ask yourself how you feel about it.....we're all different so listen to yourself. i should have had my first chemo yesterday but running a temperature so postponed.......had all my tests and my port installed so ready to go for it once I've cooled down. In my experience the lead up to making a decision is the hardest part....once a decision is made whichever way you go believe in it Best wishes for Tuesday....try to go with an open mind but loads of questions ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†

Posts.Content: Hi Angie, dealing with hair loss is a personal thing but based on my experience I'd say shave sooner, rather than later. Like you I hated the shedding, In fact clearing up the hair was more of issue for me than the actual loss of hair. Whatever you do DON'T wet shave, you don't want an open wound now your on chemo, use an electric hair trimmer which has been well cleaned before you use it. Once shaved I found giving my head a good massage a couple of times a day helped speed up the process, I used Bio oil but you could use anything similar. I think it took about 5 days to go from the scabby badger look to bald. I also had a couple of cotton beanies I wore in bed to that any shedding didn't end up in my mouth :-) In my experience this is the worst part of the hair loss, once it's gone it's amazing how quickly you get used to it and please try not to think of yourself as a cancer patient....more a warrioress doing battle with the enemy :-)) Take care Amanda

Posts.Content: Hi Michelle, firstly how lovely to hear from you but so sorry you’re have such a difficult experience.¬† I was fortunate to be referred to a specialist clinic by my insurance company, it’s called the Champalimaud Foundation in Lisbon hence my online name It’s a private clinic and as I was covered by insurance I’m not exactly sure what the costs were but would estimate around 4-6,000 euros, although this included 4 or 5 nights in hospital. They normally predicted a 3 night stay but the amount of liquid from my senoma wasn’t slowing down sufficiently, hence the extra nights.¬† I had my removal and reconstruction in one procedures which took about 4/5 hours. Couple of things to highlight, apparently the procedure is easier on slimmer small breasted ladies of which I am one, if your a larger lady, the procedure is still fine but either they combine the LD flap with a implant or maybe do a reduction op on your other breast...obviously one to discuss with the surgeons.¬† The other is the clinic specialises in LD reconstructions, subsequently they have developed a procedure which only requires one point of entry for the surgery (under the arm pit) from which they do all the necessary surgical work, there is no scar on the back which is where most ladies get their complications or future limitations from.¬† As I’m relatively small breasted, at the time 32B, they didn’t need to take much of my back muscle. Yes there is a little tightness but most of this is down to fibrouses of the scar and on a day to day basis I don’t feel anything and it certainly doesn’t stop me from doing anything, for instance I’m a 12 handicap golfer and do yoga 4 or 5 times a week.¬† 3 years after the op. the breast has shrunk a little, it doesn’t bother me so I’m not doing anything about it, although the surgeons have offered to do a small simple procedure to balance my boobs but as long as they are health I’m happy ¬† My Breast surgeon was Dr Pedro Gouveia and my reconstruction surgeon was Dr Joao Anacleto, they both speak perfect English, in fact Dr Joao (first name only in Portugal, very informal) worked at the main Glasgow hospital and was part of the team that worked on the boy David from Peru if you remember him? ¬† Sorry I’ve gone a bit, if I can be of any further help please don't hesitate to contact me again, I'm happy to exchange email addresses via private messaging if that would be helpful.¬† wishing you all the very best¬† Amanda

Posts.Content: Hi Ladies, I had an LD reconstruction in Feb 2015. My op took 2.5 hours but I am slender and the surgeon did say it was an easier op for slimmer ladies. I was in hospital for 5 days and had drains for 10 days.¬† I had my surgery in Portugal in a clinic that specialises in this op so I only have a scar under my armpit, nothing on my back which I believe isn't the norm.¬† I had chemo and radiotherapy post surgery so difficult to say how long the recovery from the actual op was but a year on I have full movement and can do everything I could do pre op and I'm pretty sporty so regaining full movement was important for me. I had physio from the day after surgery and this continued 1 or 2 a week for about 3 mths.¬† Aesthetically the reconstruction is fantastic and unless you knew I'd had surgery I think it would be almost impossible to tell the difference between my boobs. My experience has been positive but I know others have had a more difficult time, so do some research and ask your surgeon lots of questions about the op particularly how often they do it as it is bigger surgery involving cutting and rejoining nerves in and around the muscle. I still have some numbness but nothing that effects my day to day activities. Feel free to send me a friends request if you want any more information¬† Best wishes Amanda
